newsitem.title: LEBANON: Microsoft slams Lebanon software piracy.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft slams Lebanon software piracy.

text.p: U.S. software giant Microsoft said on Tuesday 90 percent of software in Lebanon was pirated and international companies would not invest in the country until it provided copyright protection.
"The level of software piracy in Lebanon is well over 90 percent," Ahmed Chami, Microsoft's regional general manager, was quoted as saying by the Beirut Daily Star newspaper.
"The market has a long way to go before we can feel confident about the integrity of products but we are definitely committed to investing more in Lebanon if the situation changes," Chami said.
He was in Beirut to meet computer dealers and hear the problems they face in selling products.

The Daily Star also quoted Sami Nsairi, head of Lebanon's professional computer association, as saying an anti-piracy bill was under preparation and would be presented to the Lebanese parliament for its approval within a month.
"We have completed almost all the steps necessary to fight software piracy," Nsairi said.

Dealers who met Chami in Beirut pointed out that the $600 price of the Microsoft Office software package was high compared with the $1,400 local price of PCs. The same pirated software package cost $20, the Daily Star quoted them as saying.
